summary: This is an email from November 5, 2020, attaching materials for a Deputy Attorney General (DAG) meeting. It provides an overview of cases likely to generate substantial press, focusing on the sex trafficking case against Ghislaine Maxwell and mentions work on a potential resolution with another Epstein co-conspirator.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Defendant in the sex trafficking case U.S. v. Maxwell, 20 Cr. 330 (AJN), identified as an Epstein associate. The document notes motions practice in her case may draw press.

persons.name: Russell
persons.context: A colleague who, along with the email sender, is signed off on the bullet points for the DAG meeting.

connections.description: Maxwell is explicitly described as an 'Epstein associate' in the context of the sex trafficking case.

events.title: DAG Meeting Preparation
events.description: An email is sent attaching bullet points and a revised memo for a Deputy Attorney General meeting to discuss cases likely to generate substantial press.

events.title: Ongoing U.S. v. Maxwell Case
events.description: Motions practice is ongoing in the sex trafficking case against Ghislaine Maxwell. The document notes press interest may arise if she succeeds in efforts to secure the identities of specific victims.

events.title: Potential Resolution with Co-conspirator
events.description: Prosecutors are 'working on potential resolution with another Epstein co-conspirator,' indicating ongoing plea or cooperation negotiations separate from Maxwell's case.

keyFacts: The document is internal DOJ communication preparing for a high-level meeting (Deputy Attorney General) about cases expected to generate press.
It highlights the sex trafficking case against Ghislaine Maxwell (U.S. v. Maxwell, 20 Cr. 330) as a key press concern, specifically motions related to victim identities.

It reveals prosecutors were, as of November 2020, 'working on potential resolution with another Epstein co-conspirator,' indicating ongoing negotiations with at least one other individual beyond Maxwell.
The email sender and a colleague named 'Russell' had signed off on the briefing materials.
